title: The mining chief who's full of beans
text:
What do you do on the weekends?

On Saturdays at 7am, I meet a friend who runs a successful retail business, and we run for about an hour and talk. He’s taught me a lot of things about running a great retail business, and it’s totally different to a gold mining business. Then we collect some other friends from the gym and have breakfast.

Jake Klein ordered the fruit plate and a flat white. Brook Mitchell

Do you run marathons?

I’ve run marathons, ultra marathons and triathlons. I grew up in apartheid-era South Africa, when the country had to invent sports that it could be a champion at. So it has these crazy long races like the 90-kilometre Comrades Marathon.

What do you do for breakfast?

Usually a bowl of cereal at home. Special K and a bit of All-Bran with skim milk.

What time do you have your first coffee?

Advertisement

As soon as I get to work, around 8.10. It’s an eastern suburbs coffee: a large three-quarter skim flat white.

Do you have a second cup of coffee?

Yes, whenever my wonderful EA goes out. It’s usually a piccolo, about 10am.

Are you a fan of breakfast meetings?

I do them occasionally. I’m more a fan of coffee meetings.

If you have lunch at your desk, what do you have?

A poke bowl with salmon. Or sushi and salad.

Advertisement

How often do you travel?

I do a lot of travelling; that’s just in the nature of the mining industry. I used to go to China every six weeks. I go to each of our five mine sites probably once a quarter. There’s one in NSW, one in Western Australia and four in Queensland, one of which is run by Glencore.

When you’re at remote mines, what happens to your exercise routine?

I try to exercise. I’ve run in some great places. This job has given me opportunities to visit these country towns and meet amazing people. The thing about the gold industry is it takes you to places where you’d pay to go on holiday. We did these road shows in New York and London. It’s a privilege to be able to travel to these cities and have a run in the morning, or meet people.

Can you find your large three-quarter flat white out at the mines?

No, you can’t. One of the things I suggested to general managers on our sites is that good coffee would make a better morning. So most sites do have a pod machine or an espresso machine.

Do you ever have times when you feel stressed or overwhelmed?

Advertisement

The thing that gives me the biggest stress is people decisions. And you can never avoid them. We talk about having honest and courageous conversations at Evolution, and that means both ways. People need to say what’s on their mind. Evolution hasn’t got there yet but I am convinced it’s the pathway to building a great company.

When you’re away, do you have breakfast in the hotel?

Usually, although I think it’s the biggest rip-off of hotel stays.

Do you have any food vices?

Only coffee. And I think my kids and wife would say my exercise is a bit of a vice. Later in life I might think maybe I shouldn’t have done that every day.

The bill

Bambini Trust, St. James Trust Building, 185 Elizabeth St, Sydney.

Two strong flat whites: $10

Fruit plate: $16

Total: $26
description: Evolution Mining boss Jake Klein says his biggest vice is coffee, with exercise a close second.
